title: Treasury yields edge higher ahead of Fed officials’ speeches
text:
U.S. Treasury yields edged higher on Friday ahead of speeches from members of the Federal Open Market Committee, the U.S. central bank’s rate-setting body, after they voted to lower rates by a quarter point this week.

What’s driving Treasurys?

The 10-year Treasury note yield TMUBMUSD10Y, -0.43% was up 0.5 basis point to 1.778%, while the 2-year note rate TMUBMUSD02Y, -0.18% rose 0.9 basis point to 1.749%. The 30-year bond yield TMUBMUSD30Y, -0.77% was mostly unchanged at 2.214%.

What are Treasurys doing?

Investors will turn their attention to speeches from senior Federal Reserve officials including New York Fed President John Williams and Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren. Their remarks could shed light on the divisions within the central bank on the need for further rate cuts, after this week’s meeting of the FOMC highlighted the disagreement among its ranks on whether additional easing was warranted.

See: Fed lowers interest rate by a quarter-point, and is open to the idea of more easing

St. Louis Fed President James Bullard published a commentary explaining the reasons for his dissent at this week’s Fed meeting. Bullard wanted a half point cut because inflation continued to run well below the central bank’s 2% target, and an aggressive move to ease policy would “provide insurance against further declines in expected inflation and a slowing economy subject to elevated downside risk.”

The Fed will conduct its fourth overnight repurchasing operation of the week on Friday at 8:15 a.m. Eastern. The U.S. central bank has started to regularly intervene into short-term funding markets to keep the fed funds rate within the Fed’s target range, currently between 1.75% to 2.00%.

What did market participants’ say?

“With the lack of economic data today, the bond market should take direction from equity markets or from geopolitical concerns,” wrote Tom di Galoma, managing director of Treasurys trading at Seaport Global Securities, in a note.
